SP.P: True, Sir John, that is as you take it; but the point is, your spouse is the damsel, on whom my kinsman has promised to bestow his bounty, and as he is ready to fulfil his part of the agreement, he thinks he has a right to insist on the performance of covenants on the part of the bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! I see you are disposed to be merry with me, Sir Wilful.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Gadso, but I am very serious, Sir John. The maiden, never dreaming it would be her lot to meet with a husband, who should object to the condi∣tion of the obligation, thought there was no harm in thus providing herself with something to begin the world with. But, if you refuse your consent, to be sure, the landlord must forego his claim.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Consent! Confound his claim and his cove∣nant too! I'll shoot him through the head, for having the insolence to mention it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: And me through the heart at the same time, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: Since all must come out, Sir, it is in vain to deny that I love this landlord.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Love him! Sir Wilful's kinsman! the lord of the manor!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: The same, Sir.

LG.L: Let lord and husband have his due;
I yield to each his part;
For when I gave my hand to you,
I gave to him my heart.
While your commands I, then, obey,
And prove a loving wife;
O'er him, Oh! let me bear the sway,
A mistress, lov'd for life.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Mighty loving, indeed! I thank you for your love, Madam. —But what can you see in me so absurd as to attempt thus to impose upon me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: Take care you don't impose on your∣self, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: 'Sdeath, Madam! who is this landlord? — Let me see him. What's his name? Where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: If you can command your passion, Sir, you may find, yourself alone with him in the adjoin∣ing gallery, and be satisfied of his claim.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Yes, yes, Madam, he shall give me satis∣faction, depend on it. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: 'Egad, his blood circulates purely. What a confounded flurry he is in!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: I begin to pity him, Sir; he suffers too much from an imaginary evil. Let us follow him. Exeunt.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, Another Apartment in the Manor-house.
Enter Sir John Manly in great agitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Confusion! What can I make of all this? [Looking anxiously about.] I see nobody.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Townly, in man's cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Ah, ha! here he comes. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Town.
SP.P: [Aside.] So far, so good. Now, if I can but steal undiscovered to her dressing-room— Walks on tip-toe across the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: [Coming forward and stopping her.] Yes, Sir; but you don't steal undiscovered to her dressing-room, I assure you,. 'Sdeath, Sir! how dare you have the impudence to think a gentleman would suffer such an insult? Draw this moment, or— Drawing his sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Town.
SP.P: Bless me, Sir! What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: You know very well what's the matter, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Town.
SP.P: The deuce take me, if I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Come, come, draw, my little rampant lord land'ord.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Town.
SP.P: Landlord: The deuce a landlord am I, Sir. Not a mansion, hovel, or tenement have I in the whole county—Nay, Sir, I am only tenant at will to the cloaths on my back.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: It is in vain to trifle. You were sneaking to her dressing-room. Draw, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Town.
SP.P: Not I, Sir, without some better reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Dost thou talk of reason too, thou con∣temptible little animal?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs.
SP.P: Town. Yes, faith, do I. And I think it very hard, for a man who has just fallen in one duel, to be taken up so soon by a second.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Do you laugh at me, Sir? Advancing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Town.
SP.P: Hold, hold, Sir! I tell you I have been shot once to-day already. You would not go to kill me again.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Insolent trifler! —Defend yourself this mo∣ment, or, by heavens— Puts himself in a posture of defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Town.
SP.P: Nay, then, it is well I secured my fire∣arms. Aside.

LG.L: The man is stark mad without doubt!
And this for my safety expedient— Presents a pistol to Manly, who retires.
To the right, if you please—Wheel about—
'Tis well, Sir—So—There—Your obedient. Crosses the stage, and exit.

DIV2.STAGE: Manet Manly, with his sword drawn, in great confusion.
Sir Wilful and Lady Lucy enter at folding doors that open in the centre of the scene.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! What, fencing with the air, man? Fighting with your own shadow?

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: It is well, Sir, that your age and house pro∣tect you. As for you, Madam, I have learned to de∣spise you, since I have seen the thing on which you had placed your affections.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: What thing, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: That toy of silk and tinsel, that went out just now. Bullies should be made of more substantial stuff. But, thank Heaven, our marriage is not con∣summated, nor ever shall. I'll sue out a divorce, or ride post to Japan, but I'll get rid of this affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: [to Lady Lucy.] Codso! We shall carry this joke too far here: the man's brain is turned in good earnest.— [To Manly.] Why, Sir John, there was nobody here but in your own imagination.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Away! thou egregious old coxcomb. Putting up his sword and going.

LG.L: Oh, stay! Ah, turn, my only dear!
The sportive trial's too severe;
It pains me thus to grieve you.
Leave not in rage your faithful bride.
But lay your fears and frowns aside,
And let her undeceive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: 'Sdeath, Madam! What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: I mean, Sir, that you yourself are the favourite landlord in question. It is you who gave me the promise of your whole fortune for my wed∣ding-portion. —It is you to whom I have given both my hand and heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: It is even so, Sir John. This is my niece Lucy, late Lady of the Manor; and you my new kinsman, who have entered, it seems, into a matrimo∣nial contract to go to bed together. You see you have stumbled on a fortune without knowing it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; and I now give you my por∣tion in possession, in return for yours in promise. —This morning I was mistress of this mansion, with all the pastures and plowed fields within two miles round. At present they are yours: you are their owner now, lord of this manor and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Is it possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Oh, yes, it is very possible that things should be as they are. Well, Sir John, what say you now? Shall the marriage be consummated or not? Shall the landlord have his due? or will you shoot him through the head? Sue out a divorce, or ride post to Japan, to get rid of this affair? Hah?

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: I am dumb with admiration.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: I was resolved, Sir, never to venture on a husband, till I was convinced that my person, ra∣rather than my fortune, was his aim. —That proof you have generously given me; and I am rejoiced that I can make you this grateful return. —You must impute the artifices, I have used in procuring this assurance, to the design concerted between you and your friend, for the disposal of both my person and fortune without my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: I own it; with blushes I own it. How shall I repay thy generosity? —Give me thy hand, thy lips, thy heart; there let me dwell, and be for ever happy. Embraces her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: There, there; so, so. All's compos'd again. Egad, I was afraid you were non compos, when you talked of meeting a bully here.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: By heavens, I encountered an insolent boy, who with fire arms set me at defiance and retired.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: Mrs. Townly, as I live, returning from her expedition against Mr. Wildman; who is in con∣sequence, you see, taken into custody. You must join with us in inflicting a little imaginary punishment too on your friend.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Wildman, guarded by a Constable and other country fellows: with Farmer Sternold, who goes up to Lady Lucy and converses with her aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: [To Sir Wilful.] An please your worship, we have apprehended a vagrom here, who has committed a murder, as I may say, in Farmer Sternold's close. And so we have brought him to take his exami∣nation afore your worship, and be committed to gaol.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Murder! say you? Whom has he mur∣dered?

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P:
Nea, nea, I did na see the dead mon, to be sure, to ask'un. But the fellow and he, beliken, had
some words about their sweethearts, and so he shot'un that's aw.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [To Wildman.] I always told you, George, what these wild doings would bring you to; but you would still run riot upon every thing. What could you expect?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Yes, faith, we have made a very fine expedi∣tion of it. One of us is married to a jilt, and the other will be hanged for killing her bully.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: A fair confession. Where's John, clerk! Here, let him make out the fellow's mittimus. I'll dispatch him to the county jail, in an instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: To the county jail! Sir John, you will be bound for my appearance at the assizes.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: As to that, George, I must beg to be excused. I am sorry for you, but a murder is serious affair, and the law must take its course.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Ay, certainly—Where's John, clerk! The vagrant stands committed.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Then, Sir, for the sake of your family, I must be so free as to acquaint you who I am. Look at me, Sir, are my features unknown to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Gadso! Where's my spectacles! Let me see—Ay, sure enongh, the very fellow that I commit∣ted to Lincoln jail for horse-stealing! Egad, friend, if yours be a family phiz, it is a very unpromising one, I can assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: And yet, Sir, I am your nephew, George Wildman.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: My nephew! you George Wildman!

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Tis too true, Sir Wilful, and I cannot help reflecting on the sagacity of your late prediction. The young gentleman will certainly come to be hanged, as you said.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: True, but I did not think I should have the trouble of signing his mittimus.

SP.SPEAKER: Stern.
SP.P:
With your worship's leave; as the culprit
proves to be a kinsman of yours, and I am the only wit∣ness that can convict him; if he should chuse to supply the place of the poor girl's sweetheart he has killed, and marry her, my evidence, you know, on that con∣dition—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: No, thou rascally old pandar.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Nay, no abuse, friend; you have your choice. It is a fair offer; the girl or the gallows.

LG.L: Does the foolish fellow faulter?
Pr'ythee make no more delay;
Take the wench or take the halter,
Stand not shill-I, shall-I, pray.
While there's life, man, there is hope,
Take the wife and leave the rope.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY LUCY.
SP.L: Sarce can I refrain from laughter.

LG.L: Mayn't the man be hang'd hereafter,
When to wife and husband too—

SP.SPEAKER: STERNOLD.
SP.L: The rope may prove a friend—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILFUL.
SP.P: That's true.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Townly, in man's cloathes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Townly.
SP.P: Hey day! What's the matter here! All appear surpriz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Ha! my little bully alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Townly.
SP.P: My antagonist in custody! I expected as much. You may release him, gentlemen, as I am unhurt. My foot only slipped, and my friend, the far∣mer, here, took the alarm before I could recover myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Let me embrace you, my little bravo. Runs to embrace Mrs, Townly, who retires.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Town.
SP.P: Nay no more rudeness, Sir, at your pe∣ril. My Uncle Sternold is here to protect me. Don't you know his niece. Laura, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: How! Laura!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: [After conferring with Lady Lucy, aside.] Very frolicksome truly all this! A pretty piece of work, you young folks have made of it here. But come, come, it is my turn to have a frolick now. Look you here Mr. Scapegrace, I dare say, tho' Mrs. Laura did not chuse to be a mistress, she will have no objec∣tions to be made a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Townly.
SP.P: Sir Wilful.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Silence, hussy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Townly.
SP.P: But, Sir Wilful!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: How, Sir! a farmer's daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Ay, sirrah, or you shall inherit no farm lands of mine. A farmer's daughter, booby! Why every woman is somebody's daughter. But you're out, you rogue, this is Mrs. Townly, Sir, a London lady of fa∣mily and fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Mrs. Townly! Nay then I am caught in a snare, I thought I had escaped. Folly, I see, makes one as blind as love; I should else have sooner recol∣lected those features I have so often admired. May I hope, Madam— To Mrs. Townly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs.
SP.P: Townly. Nay don't talk to me about your hopes, I know nothing of the matter. Sir Wilful seems to dispose of us all as his property; but—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: But what, hussy? Come take her hand, boy, take her hand. If you can venture for once on a wife, I warrant she'll venture twice on a husband. Wildman takes Mrs Townly's hand and eagerly kisses.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Townly.
SP.P: Hold, hold, Sir; no more. Sir Wil∣ful seems positive, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Again! at your buts?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lucy.
SP.P: Nay, cousin, pay some regard, for my sake, to the hasty example before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Which if they don't follow, adod, I'll make such an example of them—

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Never fear, Sir Wilful. I'll be bound for my friend's appearance at the assizes now. At the same time, take notice, George, that however you, libertines, may affect to turn matrimony into ridicule, there is no lasting bliss but in honourable love.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Right, Sir John: And here I see are our neighbours and tenants assembled to wish you joy on the occasion. Let them all come in—you must know it is our sheepshearing time, and we must make a ge∣neral holiday of it.

LG.L: False and flattering is the kiss
Of the fickle faithless miss.
True and faithfully for life,
Loves a chaste endearing wife.
Marriage might indeed have joys,
Youth so true to beauty.
Laughing girls and blooming boys,
Blessing love and duty.
Joy, then, to the wedded pair!
Joy unmix'd with sorrow!
Hold you there—an hour of care
Must bid an heir good-morrow.
Joy, then, to the wedded pair!
Joy, unmix'd with sorrow!
Till the birth-day hour of care,
Bid girl or boy good-morrow.
